name: 2-amino-5-chloro-3-fluoropyridine
Reason: 2-amino-5-chloro-3-fluoropyridine has a melting point that we will compare to benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The basic unit for our comparison is the pyridine ring, which has a melting point of around 100°C. The introduction of a fluorine atom generally increases the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and the rigidity of the structure. The chlorine atom also raises the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and the potential for hydrogen bonding. The amino group introduces a basic nitrogen, which can participate in hydrogen bonding, lowering the melting point. The fluorine atom also introduces a rigid structure, which can participate in dipole interactions, raising the melting point. The chlorine atom can also participate in dipole interactions, although to a lesser extent. The net effect is a complex interplay of structural components, with the fluorine atom contributing more significantly than the chlorine atom due to its increased molecular weight and rigidity.
